review_title: My thoughts on UT Austin employment
pros: Working for UT Austin conveys a lot of benefits, such as a defined pension program (deferred compensation, effectively), generous leave policies, and decent insurance. There are also educational benefits some staff can take advantage of.
cons: The downside of UT Austin is your experience will vary widely. UT is intentionally federated, which means each college, school, or unit defines their own internal processes and procedures; for example some staff in one department may be able to take advantage of work from home while staff in another will not be able to, because the local director forbids it. The culture is local and which unit you end up working for will have a big impact on your overall job satisfaction. As a state employee, your salary and holidays are largely defined by the state legislature, and Texas is not a state friendly to the civil servant. A consequence of this is compensation lags other area businesses. Furthermore, while there is a pension program, it is of highest value to those who start young and stay for decades; employees who are looking to explore various career opportunities at multiple companies will find the package lacking in value.

review_title: It is what you make of it
pros: There are very few admin jobs at UT Austin, and they can be okay. There is some support. If your job allows it and you're accepted, you can pay to go to school slowly. Inter-department transfers are possible.
cons: It's just an odd environment as it's a state school that acts like a private corporation. Lots of private donors, all departments are siloed, the Gov and state legislature get way more involved than they should be. It's preferred that candidates assimilate into the burnt orange football culture and not stand out. Every staff, faculty member, and student must pay to park. And they kick you out of certain parking garages during football events. Some people retire and keep their garage parking benefits. This and the commute can take the fun right out of any job.

pros: UT Austin has some serious donors, are great at acquiring funding, and will likely be a U.S. research leader in the next decade. Is attracting a lot of high quality talent. Grad student career support is excellent.
cons: UT has a high tolerance for bullying and you should too if you work there. Ridiculously low salaries for city living. Career suffers from poor group management. Uncomfortable work environment (racism, sexism, classism). No meaningful career support for young PIs or postdocs.

review_title: Excellent environment but very low pay
pros: The environment at UT is amazing - a lot of alumni choose to work at the school, and the sense of community is really nice. You also have the opportunity to work in an area that interests you, even if you aren't a practitioner (language, science, art, etc.) I'm still astonished that I had the opportunity to work with such interesting, dedicated people and feel very grateful for that.
cons: At least initially, administrative staff are paid far below the market value. This may improve a little as you move up, but you will never make enough to live comfortably, especially if you're a single income person or family. The math just doesn't work. I left before 2019, but that's as far back as it allows you to select in the box - but I just checked a current listing for the same position and was shocked to see the pay rate is the same as it was when I was there. Austin has not been a particularly affordable to live since the 90s, but now it's very expensive. I would love to return to an environment like that, but frankly, I can't afford to work at UT. I don't know how they justify paying so little to the people who keep the place running. (And I don't know if they still do, but at that time, they charged employees quite a lot for a parking pass! What is that?!)

review_title: Satisfaction depends on which department you're in
pros: I am lucky to have awesome coworkers who are similarly invested in learning and growing. The UT students I work with are enthusiastic and motivated, so that has been rewarding. There is some flexibility in WFH vs on-campus, as well as the hours which I work.
cons: Extremely uneven resources and out-of-touch leadership. Some programs are well-funded, while others are working with a skeleton crew - there's a lot of turnover as a result. This unevenness resonates outward, causing a lot of systemic issues, lack of communication, and impacts the ability for staff and faculty to do their jobs. Some of the initiatives moving back to in-person presence after COVID-19 are nonsensical, and even the students are overwhelmed and burning out in the push to pretend like everything is normal.

review_title: Nice people, lousy pay and benefits, parasitic management
job_title: Senior Software Developer/Analyst in Austin, TX
pros: The people on the ground at UT in the software community are great people. I can't say enough good things about them. Working for the university felt good and like you were making a difference in people's lives. It's a great place to learn software development and get a start on your career.
cons:
The people in power here, as anywhere, but massively infuriating at a supposedly not-for-profit educational institution, are some of the most egotistical, short-sighted, therapy-needing individuals I have ever met. Power trips, reorgs galore, mismanaged funds, passing the blame to anyone they can pin their bad decisions on. No one above the rank-and-file does anything useful and spends most of their time jockeying for status and influence instead of doing their jobs. 

The pay and turnover are also terrible and no one cares that the workers leave in droves because there's always fresh meat to take over. Almost no one in software stays here more than a few years.

No diversity to speak of, rampant bias in hiring and promotions, active and known and protected sexual harassers and racists in the community.

job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Austin, TX
pros: Working with highly educated, interesting people. Faculty and leadership (in my department, anyway) are generally very nice and appreciative of the work the staff does. Flexible schedule with the ability to work from home several days per week. Great insurance and benefits. Occasional parking program is a great option for staff who aren't in the office full time. Moody College has a good dean and seems to be one of the better places to work at UT in my experience.
cons: Low pay, difficult to advance unless you switch departments. Getting a full-time parking permit is a pipe dream, since the university prioritizes faculty and leadership (they get to cut the waitlist line so that a lowly staff member doesn't really stand a chance of ever getting to the top). Very hierarchical culture, even among the staff - there are some grumpy lifers who like to make newer staff feel inferior and are unwilling to share their knowledge. As others have mentioned, the more you prove your competence, the more work gets piled on (with no additional pay).

cons: One of the biggest issues I have had with working in the UT system is that positions lower than managers (even ones that require a masters degree) are very much treated as disposable. I saw examples of this in my own experience, but also the turnover rate in student-facing roles all across campus (again, masters level, licensed, 10+ years of experiences, etc..), in the disproportionately low salaries in comparison to regional universities and community colleges, and the lack of upward mobility. UT is an amazing university, and I would imagine it is a great university to be a manager, director, faculty, or dean at, but working in a student-facing role was not worth it.

pros:
I really feel like there's always opportunities to promote here at UT. Myself, I am moving to a new department.
I will be coming from Housing & Dining and moving on to Parking &Transportation. I don't believe the pay is any better, but this is a method I am using to transition away from the service industry and focus more on administrative work-which I feel I am better suited to handle. In summation, working at UT I have always felt like it's easy and encouraged to keep moving up. 
 They are understanding, flexible, smart and hard working faculty and staff . 
 It's a busy environment that helps the days go by.
 Your employee ID gives you access to free CapMetro busses!
 They are always throwing employee appreciation parties 🥳 with great food and fun things
cons:
We are short staffed. *everyone* is hiring right now. Training can sometimes miss important aspects of the work, causing a lot of problems. You have to park away from UT because of course it's full of staff and students. Even being able to get a parking permit means you've come up on the waitlist lol. Other cons- frankly, they don't pay enough. Which is probably why they're staffed and have remained so for a while now.
Free food! Lol you are given a "stipend" so to speak that acts as a lunch money account. We use our employee ID'S to pay for our meals at restaurants and dining halls ♡

For administrative roles, the salary is extremely low - I have a master's degree and could not have stayed long term, if only because I couldn't afford to. (2018 was the most recent option - I left a few years prior, but checked a couple of listings and it has not improved much if at all. Effectively the pay has dropped.) Many facilities and offices are dated and decrepit; the money seems to go to the higher-profile programs like sport and media.

cons:
- Low pay for all staff roles and can't compete with Austin tech market. 
- Staff is treated poorly compared to faculty. An example - staff receive an annual 2% cost of living raise while faculty receive an annual 3% cost of living raise. FOR WHAT REASON? WE ALL LIVE IN THE SAME CITY?
- No vertical movement (even a promotion within the same department) during the first six months in a role - my superior left and instead of me being promoted to that role, I just had to do all of the extra work for free for 3 months until I could be promoted instead. I honestly should have left then - extra work for no extra pay? I wont ever do that again

review_title: Good environment, good people, horrible bureaucracy
job_title: Research Scientist Associate III in Austin, TX
pros: Top tier health insurance, nice environment
cons: Inflexible pay, no opportunity for raises, managers/PIs do not have the power to give your promotions or raises. Inscrutable bureaucracy which cannot be navigated easily. Academics aside, (who are there to pursue their degrees/passions) everyone is paid less than the job market in Austin (2021) would suggest. However, it is a stable job, with good benefits and pension. In this sense, it is a "government job," where everyone is pretty competent, but all the people who could really make more elsewhere don't stick around. (Again I am referring to staff, not students or faculty.) I left my current position because, despite my PI having the funds and desire to pay me more, it was not allowed by the board. Furthermore, I discovered through a public records request that people with my exact title on my team were being paid much more. The system as a whole is totally unresponsive to any salary concerns. Edicts about raises or lack thereof (None in your first year, none during covid, and one less than inflation in 2021) come from on high in the form of a "salary letter" with no way to communicate with anyone who made the decision. My PI, who would like to retain me, feels helpless as me in this situation.

job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Austin, TX
pros: Good insurance, flexible schedules, good work/life balance, pleasant campus to work at, mandatory retirement pension. There are lots of benefits of working for UT if you happen to be lucky enough to get into a good department/unit with a good manager and good coworkers. If you have the right mentor and your boss cares about employees, there are tons of opportunities available at UT, and it can be a very pleasant and satisfying place to work. My first 4 years at UT were great.
cons: Low pay compared to similar jobs in the private sector, managers are generally only interested in maintaining the status quo, and opportunities for advancement, further training, and education depend greatly on what unit you work in and if you have a boss who sees value in those things. The first few years I worked at UT were fine; however, after my unit got a new director (in 2018) everything went downhill extremely fast (I worked in GIAC - the Graduate and International Admissions Center). Within months, it became the most toxic and miserable place I'd ever worked. There was a clear pattern of nepotism and favoritism, employees were blatantly discriminated against and bullied (by the director!!), along with being shut out or retaliated against (again, by the director). It was toxic, unprofessional, and frankly embarrassing to work there. People started to very wisely jump ship almost immediately, and that meant piling on extra work to those who still worked there, while delaying hiring replacements for YEARS. I tried to stick it out purely for my coworkers, but eventually found a better job at UT, and only wish I'd done it sooner. You learn pretty quickly that competence only gets you more and more work, but without any comparative raise in title or pay. And UT's HR -- like HR at any other company -- exists only to protect the company, not the employees. If you find yourself in a similarly bad situation, the best bet is just to quit and find a job elsewhere on campus. I would avoid working at GIAC like the plague, but other departments have the potential to be pretty good.

review_title: It could be great, but there is high turnover for a reason
job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros:
There are really incredible and committed people, but sadly the best talent have moved on or are actively searching for new jobs. There are still some of the best and most committed professionals I know in the international education field working there, who I genuinely admire and enjoy a colleagues.

Flexible work schedules have been great, but they are not the same for every role, so if you are interviewing make sure to ask about the specific unit you want to work with!

UT Austin has great resources and you are able to tap into those resources as a staff member (be warned that UT has limited tuition reimbursement, particularly for graduate programs).

In the world of international education getting hit hard by COVID, there is still a lot happening at UT Austin/Texas Global, but be ready for it to be a challenge given the poor senior leadership who is more concerned about appearances then doing the work of supporting employees in the mission of the office.
cons:
Poor senior leadership is the root cause of most issues. Directors are capable professionals who are stressed and strained and are not encouraged or supported when they push back, advocate for their staff, and/or seek out help. If they are successful in getting what they need, it is a fight and they have the scars to prove it.

Understandably, the office is trying navigate new office environments, but they are slow to adapt.

While it is great that there were recent pay increases, the office is still one of the lowest paid across the university and the pay increases have not been entirely equitable across units. Despite university and HR bureaucracy, it is important that titles match salaries and that there are clear paths for promotions.

review_title: NASCENT: not a good place for career development as a postdoc
pros:
- Working on industrial projects

- Good place to live at (Austin, TX)
cons:
- The group I was part of, i.e. NAnomanufacturing Systems CENTer (NASCENT), was working mainly on industrial projects. As a result, the nature of work is industrial for external customers, while earning a relatively low salary from the academia.

- Not being able to publish high-quality works when working at NASCENT, because: 1. works are mainly appealing to the customers from industry, but not necessarily to the scientific community, and 2. most of the contents are confidential, which makes the publication of even a mediocre conference/journal paper cumbersome due to the required paperwork and the process of getting approval from the customers.

- The professor I was working in their group was an entrepreneur/businessperson, which made it very hard to find and talk to them. Emails are mostly ignored, sometimes even after sending multiple reminders. It caused a bad impression when applying to other positions, since the requests made by other employers for providing the reference letter were ignored, although my professor had given their consent to be listed as a reference.

- With little to no opportunity to progress, NASCENT is not a good place for career development as a postdoc.

Combined with the precarious grant funding situation, ineffective communication between the two sides of the organization, and a few truly toxic employees, it was enough to make me look for opportunities elsewhere.

review_title: Good part-time work for full-time students
pros:
As long as you show up for the big game days and events - which end up being really long days or whole weekends - the work schedule is otherwise very flexible.

Most of the managers are easy to work for and work with.

It can be an exciting place to work, especially if you're into college sports. And you could do worse if you're trying to get a foot in the door for a permanent position with intercollegiate athletics.
cons:
This is a big professional sports organization in all but name, and it comes with all the trappings and bureaucratic red tape. It's also technically a government job so you can expect more of the same there.

Logistically, departments struggle to coordinate and for all their resources will often find themselves shorthanded. The left hand seldom knows what the right hand is doing even within upper management.

The business office for UT athletics caps your pay and hours as a student worker. You can earn more and work regular hours as a cashier or office intern in the inner campus.

review_title: TA/GRA positions come w/ significant benefits at the cost of extending school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: 20hr/wk positions come with significant benefits in the form of health insurance (12 months of coverage if position is continued following semester), in state tuition as well as "tuition reduction benefit" which covers a significant portion of remaining tuition.
cons:
The Architecture School does not pay as much as other departments do. Architecture students may find GRA/TA positions elsewhere, such as in the Fine Art School. Mentoring athletes is also an option.

Since Architecture is so demanding you will in all likelihood have to take fewer courses per semester (the "full load" of 15 credits is insane) ... this will extend graduation, cost of living expenses, postpone making income. Students should consider the considerable opportunity costs in their calculus.

job_title: Electrical Distribution Electrician in Austin, TX
pros: UT Austin employee benefits are pretty good i.e. PTO, sick leave, and health benefits, but not exclusive to UEM or Electrical distribution, any full time university employee receives them. I would sit down and have a beer with everyone I worked with at UEM at any time, I made lifelong friends and I think that everyone from top down is capable of doing good.
cons:
The electrical distribution shop is undermanned, which causes unnecessary stress on both the employees and supervision. Little to no training is provided to new hires, so they have to rely on learning things through “experienced” veteran employees who themselves only learned what they know from other “experienced” employees, which has turned into a dangerous game of telephone that has left the employees with garbled knowledge from the 1980s and ill prepared during emergencies, without the skills necessary to accomplish the job in an efficient, safe, and correct manner. Most utilities that work with distribution equipment and medium/high voltage electricity have actual training courses and apprenticeship programs, and are constantly taught the best and safest way to do their job, that is not the case here. The actual workers are a joy to be around and make the best of the situation, however the overall attitude towards supervision is that they lack the experience and skills to lead, and they definitely do not have your back. 
The pay is sub-standard for the industry, unless you’re the supervisor, who sits at almost
40,000 dollars more than the average worker. The lack of competitive pay has left the shop unable to hire anyone with actual lineman/electrical distribution experience, and ultimately lead to severe undermanning issues.

review_title: Warning: DON'T WORK HERE - A house divided cannot stand
pros: The actual officers are kind and helpful.
cons:
- No vision here from leadership
- Very time consuming meetings that lead to more confusion
- Policies in place are implemented differently dependent upon "favoritism" 
- Command will ask for feedback and then minimize your feedback and attempt to make you feel stupid like there is no real issue present 
- Schedule changes approx. 2 times a month on average 
- People call out sick so be prepared to work the entire campus as one officer with one sgt that will often sit in the office and not even have the radio on
- Politicking is everything here. If you know the right person you'll get out of DWI's, bad policing behavior, negative body camera footage, etc. 
- Promotion boards are ambiguous and everyone already knows who will get promoted before they even board 
-There are "divisions" but they expect different groups not to look down on others. Some officers will be patrolling the whole shift while others sit in a room and just talk the whole time 
- You'll bring all this to command and they'll tell you things like "oh i've never heard that before" 
- Rotating sgts for night shifts is not ideal

pros: A great place to work if you are a student on campus who needs a job. They are (like most) work study jobs flexible with your class schedules and you learn about so many resources that are available to you about resumes, cover letters, career prep/discovery and more that will be applicable to you when you graduate
cons: I don't have any cons for now

pros: The UT Benefits are good.
cons: Staff are not respected by faculty or upper administration. They can be let go on a whim by admin who are not direct supervisors, and there is no process for delivering feedback, or working to resolve issues if they arise. Also, the salaries for staff are not liveable. Most staff have second or third jobs to support their low UT salaries which lead to massive burnout.
